title: 104_s1112
content: The "Food Stamp Anti-Fraud Act of 1995" expands the definition of coupons and doubles penalties for violating food stamp program requirements. It also grants authority to establish authorization periods. The Food Stamp Anti-Fraud Act of 1995 grants authority to establish specific time periods for authorization to accept and redeem coupons under the food stamp program. Additionally, it establishes a specific period for prohibiting participation of stores based on lack of business integrity. Section 9(a)(1) of the Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to allow the Secretary to establish specific time periods for stores with denied or withdrawn applications based on business integrity to reapply. The severity of infractions will determine the length of the prohibition. SEC. 6 amends Section 9(c) of the Food Stamp Act to allow for the submission of relevant income and tax documents. Retail food stores and wholesale food concerns may be required to provide written authorization for the Secretary to verify tax filings and obtain corroborating documentation. SEC. 7 introduces a waiting period for stores that initially fail to meet authorization criteria. Section 9(d) of the Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to impose a 6-month waiting period for retail food stores or wholesale food concerns whose application to accept coupons is denied due to not meeting approval criteria set by the Secretary. SEC. 8. Amends the Food Stamp Act to include refunds of Federal taxes as a mandatory claims collection method. Also, updates the Act to ensure collection of debts through various means, including refunds of Federal taxes. SEC. 9 amends the Food Stamp Act to establish criteria for violations leading to suspension or disqualification of retail or wholesale food stores. Evidence for such actions may include on-site investigations, redemption data, or transaction reports under electronic benefits transfer systems. SEC. 10 addresses disqualification of stores pending judicial and administrative review. The Food Stamp Act is amended to allow for the suspension of retail or wholesale food stores found in violation of program requirements. The Secretary will not be liable for any lost sales during a suspension period. Additionally, Section 14 is amended to include the possibility of suspension in addition to disqualification for violations. The Food Stamp Act is amended to allow for the suspension of retail or wholesale food stores for violations. The suspension will remain in effect during any review process and will be considered part of any disqualification period imposed. SEC. 11. DISQUALIFICATION OF RETAILERS UNDER THE WIC PROGRAM. Section 12 of the Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to include criteria for disqualifying retail stores and wholesale food concerns that are disqualified from the WIC program. Disqualification terms align with the WIC program's disqualification period. SEC. 12. Permanent debarment of retailers who intentionally submit falsified applications, leading to disqualification from the program without judicial or administrative review. Section 12 of the Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to include regulations for permanent disqualification of retail or wholesale food stores that submit false information in their application. Disqualification is subject to review but remains in effect during the process. Section 15 of the Act (7 U.S.C. 2024) is amended to include criminal forfeiture for individuals convicted of violating subsections (b) or (c) involving food stamp benefits worth $5,000 or more. Offenders must forfeit any benefits, property obtained from the violation, and any property used in committing the violation. Section 15 of the Act (7 U.S.C. 2024) now includes criminal forfeiture for individuals convicted of violating subsections (b) or (c) involving food stamp benefits worth $5,000 or more. Offenders must forfeit all property described in the subsection and follow specific procedures outlined in the Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970. Excluded property under this subsection does not apply to property mentioned in subsection (g). The Act and its amendments will be effective on October 1, 1995, unless otherwise specified.
